750 ml bottle into tulip glass; Batch #4, bottled in 10/2015. Pours slightly hazy/cloudy golden yellow color with a 2 finger fairly dense and fluffy white head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Damn nice aromas with great complexity and balance of fruity/spicy/earthy yeast and light-moderate pale malt notes; with great strength. Taste of big lemon, lime, grapefruit, pineapple, peach, pear, melon, peppercorn, wheat, cracker, hay, straw, herbal, grass, light musty funk, light oak/vanilla, and yeast earthiness. Good amount of peppery yeast spiciness on the finish; with lingering notes of lemon, lime, grapefruit, pineapple, peach, pear, melon, peppercorn, wheat, cracker, hay, straw, herbal, grass, light musty funk, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Damn nice complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/spicy/earthy yeast and light-moderate pale malt flavors; with a great malt/spiciness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Moderate dryness from carbonation and yeast spiciness as well. Medium-high carbonation and light-medium body; with a very smooth crisp, and lightly creamy/bready/sticky balanced mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is very well hidden with zero warming present after the finish. Overall this is an excellent Brett saison. All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/spicy/earthy yeast and light-moderate pale malt flavors; and very smooth, crisp, and easy to drink. A very enjoyable offering.

This is much more of a sour ale than what we think of as saison nowadays. I very much appreciate some tartness in saisons, but...this is full on puckeringly *sour*, virtually lambic level. Which is perhaps historically accurate if we¬íre talking pre-WW2, spontaneously fermented varieties. But at a hefty 6% ABV, that¬ís obviously not what they were trying to reproduce. This "sour saison" thing seems to be a growing trend in America...which is a lot better than the trend of making sugary sweet banana bombs and calling those saison, but still...this is over the top in the acidity department. It¬ís well made otherwise, though...pleasant, mild Brett character and no banana to be found. The aroma is a bit generic as golden sour ales go, but it¬ís certainly enjoyable. Call it "Arctic Sour Ale" and I could perhaps be a little more enthusiastic about this. But if you call it a saison and come in at 6%, in that case I¬ím looking for something like Dupont or Blaugies.

Appearance: Beautiful golden hue. Crystal clear at first, but becomes quite cloudy when sediment is mixed in. Pours to a large, bright white, fluffy head which retains well but doesn¬ít lace the glass.

Smell: Strong aroma of Brettanomyces plus clean lemon scent. 

Taste: I was little nervous about drinking a nine-month-old bottle of saison, but was pleasantly surprised by how strong the flavor had remained and what was there was delicious. This is cleaner and fruitier than most saisons, and the Brett character gives is a noticeable amount of tartness and earthy character to make it more than interesting without becoming distracting.

The initial palette is fruity with distinct lemonpeel and a general clean citrus taste. White grape also appears to be quite noticeable. The Brett character emerges about halfway through the palette - giving it a discernible tartness. A hint of sour, but more accurately described as a farmhouse funk. The yeast and sediment impart some bitterness and give the palette a little more character. The residual aftertaste is quite pleasant. I didn¬ít find there to be any oak character at all, despite the label¬ís indication that it was aged in oak tanks.

Drinkability: Saisons were created to be refreshing and that¬ís exactly what Grassroots Brewing Arctic Saison is. It¬ís extremely crisp and clean and seems to cleanse the palate as it goes down. It feels much lighter than its 6% ABV weight, though it definitely has the flavor of a brew that strong. . I could see myself drinking the entire bottle solo in the summer.

A Saison by Anchorage Brewing and Hill Farmstead? Sign me up! A golden color pours out of the bottle with a big fluffy head that holds firm on top. A nice looking brew. The first whiff reveals some summer floral notes. That¬ís quickly joined by: light clove, chamomile, straw, brett, white grape, oak, and funky cheese. The aroma is nice but a little odd. In the mouth this is lightly tart, crisp, and dry. Flavors of lemon and orange citrus mixes with oak, bretty yeast, a light crackery malt, a bit of grass, and soft herbal undertones. Very well put together with great depth, but I expected nothing less from two of my favorite brewers. A bone dry and lightly bitter finish concludes this nicely. Clean, tasty, and refreshing stuff.

Bottle. Pours hazy gold, almost straw-colored, with frothy white head, leaving behind irregular lacing. Juicy citrus, light funk, bright nose. Some bubblegum. Big fruity nose. Taste: A lot less intense than the nose. Some earth, some citrus, a shade salty, a fair bit of mineral. Lightly toasted grains poke their head in. Extremely dry, sharp, lightly tart finish (described by another person tasting this as "unripe gooseberries" -- a taste I can¬ít personally identify, but maybe that description will resonate with others who read this review). Slight bitterness. Overall: Quite dry. The nose is huge and juicy, the taste is much more restrained in its intensity. It becomes a little harsh as it warms. I¬íve had this three times so far, and each time different aspects present themselves. I look forward to seeing how it changes.

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2014 Bottle to flute
Brett, bubblegum, hay, horse blanket, and lemongrass. Cloudy amber with a thick white head. Light lemon, a little bitterness, and yeast. Mouthfeel is light, smooth and creamy.

Bottle - Light lemon and farmhouse funk. Cloudy yellow with a thick bubbly white head. Soft mellow sour lemon, hay and the sour Brett. A very light bodied and mellow saison that finishes softly. Odd in that the Brett is so mild and balanced with a creamy mouthfeel.

750 ml bottle shared by b3shine. Pours a hazy golden color with a medium sized white head. The aroma and flavor have citrus, orange, lemon zest, grass, Brett more on the flavor, some funk, herbal notes. I like the complexity and clean flavors.

750 ml bottle to shifter (shared by me with the group). Looks good for the style; a cloudy light golden orange with white lacing. Smells good too; tart, yeasty, oaky, and a bit spicy. A little dampness too. Tastes like it smells with a bit of grassiness and citrus. Nice and lively on the palate with a dry, bretty finish. Good beer!

750ml bottle, shared by b3shine. Totally hazy bright yellow color. Thin white head. Nice bits and ropes of lace. Nice floral, lightly citrusy nose. Some lemon, light on the spice. Light oak. Good tart, citrusy taste. Smooth, soft moderate strength carbonation. Lightly dry in the finish. Medium-plus body. Tasty brett- saison.
Cloudy orange pour, a thumbs worth of head. Aroma of brett, sour apple, grass. Lemon and souur apple souurness, grainy, grassy, brett, a little oak aging noticeable. Lighter body.

Hazy orange with big, foamy, off-white head, decent legs / Delicate nose of orchard fruit, citrus, spice, brett / Light to medium body, lively, acidic, hint of sweetness but otherwise dry, with good fruit, excellent balance, and bitter finish / Elegant flavors of pineapple, orange, pear, coconut, coriander, hay, old sweater, oak /

Bottle much thanks to Ed for sharing. Pours out a lightly cloudy orangy color with a small white head. Aroma is of some funky Brett, light fruity yeast, grains and some mild bitterness. Taste is complex, grainy, fruity notes, funky Brett, light plastic, earth, citrus and some lingering bitterness and wild Brett. Tasty.
At the tasting at Killens BBQ ... Pours a hazy gold pear ¬Ö solid foam ¬Ö medium brett, hay and light yeast . .. Easy mouth, calm which I like .. . . Fuck you mosquito!

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2014 Bottle: Almost fully opaque golden body with a big bubbled, chunky and cloudy white head; huge, long lasting, and generous with the lace it leaves behind. Aroma is sharp Brett, mild lemon zest, blanket and cottony funk, faint must, some cracker malt, and a touch of funk Brett tartness. Taste is a ton of Brett funk. Musty, blanket, cottony and almost cheesy. Light grassy notes. Corky, with a sharp zesty hint of lemon and very faint white pepper that fades into a super funky, musty finish with a good amount of dry oak. Highly carbonated and sharp.
Bottle from City Beer. Pours a cloudy amber with a thick & creamy white head. Aromas of funk, bread and citrus. Tastes of citrus, brett and funk.

Pours a cloudy dark yellow with a nice and pillowy white head that leaves intense lacing patterns. Aroma is fruity from the brett and loaded with freshly cut hay and a nice breeze (oh so poetic...). Taste is dry and slightly tart, I believe I could drink this liter after liter... Flavors of fresh cereals, flowers, some citrus. Bitterness is there but in check, only there to provide an even drier finish. Body is medium-light with a spritzy carbonation. Ultra quaffable and refreshing. What more could we ask for? I¬íd be hard-pressed to say.
Golden, white head. Nose is light bread, citrus, grains. Taste is citrus, light brett funk. Light, clean mouthfeel. Looking forward to trying this with age.

Murky 10 karat pour with an ivory pile of suds perched atop the body. Nose shows the Brett with some sweaty, funky, grass stained socks, lemon zest, orange rind, and black pepper. Similar flavor that is light, tart, and refreshing. Tasty and a good compliment to a hot AZ summer.

Bottle, 08/26/2013. Pours hazy orange, huge fluffy white head fades to frothy foam on the surface, sticky lacing left behind. Aroma is cloud of brett and toasted pale malts, pleasant orange and mango with subtle tart green apple, dry pear. Taste is juicy orange, mango and other tropical notes, peppery brett, mild funk and dry herbal finish, light bitterness lingering. Medium body, creamy yet crisp carbonation in the finish. Very nice, looking forward to see how this evolves.
Cloudy yellow with a good white head. Aroma is lemon, dill, pepper, green olive. Tart on the palate, peppery finish. Taste is citrus peel, peppercorn, olive. Decent saison.

Bottle share. Batch #1 May 2013 bomber. Cloudy yellow orange, decent cap reduces to bubbly skim. Aroma is cheesy, wet blanket, citrus. Taste is refreshingly tart citrus, funky yeast. Balanced carbonation and dryness.

Pours a golden cloudy hay color with a nice lacy head. The nose is orange, and floral coriander. The pallet is effervescent yeast, orange, floral and coriander.

My 2nd encounter with the Jesus Juice. Drank this one right in the shower. Poured a hazy gold with a huge head. Aromas of sweat. Lightly tart, refreshing saison. That said, I¬ím still not even remotely impressed by the Jesus of Vermont¬ís beers yet.

Bottle shared by Ed, thanks brodawg. Poured a very hazed golden yellow body with an average sized foamy bright white head. Aroma was spicy, white pepper, citrus, lemons, flowers, wild honey. 750, corked and baled. Thanks, C! Pours a murky dark goldenrod. Dense creamy white head that sticks around. Big eggy nose, super funky, showing earthy minerals. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Bottle shared by Jim, thanks! Pours a hazy deep gold with a white head that dissipates to the edges and laces slightly. Aroma has a really nice funky note with underlying grapes and a touch of earthy grains. Flavor starts with light fruits with sweet grains and has a really nice funky finish.
750 ml bottle from The Beer Trappe. Pours a ton of carbonation. Big brett nose. Big lemon taste upfront. Slightly dry. Lemon citrus throughout. Yeasty. Intense.

Bottle shared with timfoolery. Solid saison with earthy notes, a bit of brett, champagne yeast, and lemon. Good beer.

Bottle courtesy of Vinny shared at Franks. Pours a bright, hazy yellow golden body with nice active white lacing. Aroma is lemon and funk. Mouthfeel is medium and evervescent with nice carbonated body; notes of lemon, funk, oak and grass. Very nice saison.

750ml bottle in a tulip. Pours hazy golden with a lacy, white head. Aroma of Brett, Some light fruits, spices, pale malts, and a light bitterness. Flavor the same with a nice Brettiness. Average texture. A good beer.
Bretty, a touch lemony & sour, nicely constructed. Bright yeast, grassy, definitely a Brett saison. Easy to drink for the style.
Bomber at my place with group. Pours orange juice color. White head that stays. Aroma is strong Bret, orange, citrus. Taste is more of the same. Finish is long and citrus. Mouthfeel is lighter.

Bottle, thanks Colin! Hazy medium yellow, small foamy head . Nice aroma - sour notes , lemon notes , dry and yeasty. Nice sour taste with a ton of dry yeast and lemon behind it . Well carbonated body accentuates the sour notes nicely . A very good sour Saison . Alcohol not present at all . Enjoy the large bottle tremendously .

Bottle from Rare Beer Club. Aroma is champagne yeast, sourdough toast, and ultra-light, meyer lemon. Lemon doesn't carry over to flavor. Really light, fluffy and a trace a bitter on the end. Palate is nice, bright champagne bubbles. Nice beer.

Cloudy yellow pour with a white head. Some nice yeast/earth and some brett. I really like this beer.
750ml corked and caged bottle. Pours a cloudy orange straw color with 2 fingers of foamy white head. Aroma citrus, hay, and Belgian funk. Taste of sour citrus, grass, hay, and Belgian funk.

750 c&c from Pangaea in Sacramento, CA. Pours very hazy gold with a foamy/creamy white head. Aroma of sour fruit and funk. Med body. Flavor is funk, sour fruit and something suggesting wheat. Pours cloudy yellow and smells oaky with zesty citrus spice and tart apples. Aroma is a little underwhelming for being barrel aged with Brett. UPDATED: AUG 17, 2013 all drafts and bottles offered. fun mineral water. clove, wet herbs. soft prickly lemongrass, wet hay, and fog.  complex, yet restrained beer.   soft and subtle. nothing harsh or abrasive about it.   unique, rustic. fun to drink. rerate bottle lifted hard.  a little too hard actually.  tight brew.

Light to medium body. The taste flirts briefly with biscuit malts, Belgian sugar, and pepper but then turns decidedly tart like grapefruit. It is this character that lingers at the end. The label says this is brewed by Anchorage Brewing of Anchorage, Alaska but the Grassroots website says their brewers traveled to Alaska to brew it. Is this the Anchorage Love Buzz in disguise?

Appearance: very hazy, deep honey gold with a thick cap of creamy white head that lasts forever; good lacing too. The brett was perfectly applied; let¬ís be honest, saisons and brett go together like peas and carrots. I¬íve never had a saison with a finish like this: so fast, so dry, so final, with that major brett kick. Very, very, very good. Bottle from the Rare Beer Club. Batch #1, May 2013.

Sour said on super awesome tangy light, thanks GT2 for the bomber, very good overall yum
Sample at the HF saison fest, very light and carbonated, almost a sletzer quality, simple and bretty. Gonna have to try one of these again later, too many at the event too quickly.
pours a hazy yellow with a fluffy white head. soft carbonation. aroma is hugely spicy with a lot of barnyard action. earthy. flavor is light crisp and spicy but fills the mouth. Good beer.

Very unappealing ugly generic label. Inside the bottle is a different story. Lovely Hazy golden color. Great beer. Ahhhh! beautiful oak. Barrel beers are heavenly. Really delicious. Perfect palate.medium body, creamy, sticky, bitter, long finish. An Amazing wedding beer.

Bottle. Pours hazy golden yellow, large foamy white head, nice lacing. Aroma is yeast, Brett, lemon, grass, pepper, touch of funk. Poured from the bottle. This was a huge disappointment. Nose is lemongrass and skunk. Very dry and crisp, but not much else. Tastes like something went wrong.
Bottle. Amber beer with an off-white head. Brett and yeast aroma. Brett and light fruity flavor with light mineral notes. Medium bodied. Brett and earthiness lingers with hay and light mineral notes.
Bottle from MJRBC , yellow soapy pour with chalky citrus aroma, flavor is chalky, lemon, tart with bit watery finish

750mL bottle. Pours a hazy golden yellow with a thick white head. Lemon, apple, some funk, slightly tart. I really liked the lemon flavor to this Saison. It made it very drinkable and refreshing.

Dry champagne like apple sour aroma with a light white head. Golden copper color with a bit of cloudiness to it. Sour saison for sure. with a bitter aftertaste. The first taste compared to the 5th are very different. Gets kinda funked after a few sips. I think it¬ís just over powering my tounge. Damn good start and kinda bland finish.

Light wet farm and spice and floral scents.
